description.value:
Biome: Jungles, Swamps

The Dripping Tree has dark brown bark, large leathery leaves, and can reach heights of about 30 ft. Its branches grow only from the very top of the trunk and spread almost horizontally like a mushroom cap, shading an area roughly 10â€“20 ft across. The roots spread and twist nearly as far as the canopy above.

Numerous cream-colored spheres, about 10 inches in diameter, cling to the branches; these globes give the tree its name. Special nodules on the roots detect movement, warmth, and pressure, causing the globes directly above a triggered area to drop. The globes are filled with viscous, sticky mucus and burst on contact; creatures hit by them become stuck to the root clusters (DC 18 Dexterity or Strength save to avoid grapple).

If pressure is continually applied to a patch of roots, the branches above slowly drip a sticky, acidic digestive mucus onto the area below (1d6 acid damage per hour). This mucus rapidly dissolves flesh and bone: small creatures (e.g., lemurs or tabibari) can be dissolved in about a day, while larger creatures and humanoids may take up to 72 hours to be reduced to nutrients.

system.source: Broderick's Compendium: Plants and Fungi Across the Realm (version 2.0)
